summary: This document is a news article about a court filing by federal prosecutors arguing that Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 plea deal must stand despite objections from victims who claim their rights were violated. The article discusses the legal dispute over whether the non-prosecution agreement should be voided due to violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy individual who entered into a 2008 plea deal that ended a federal investigation, resulting in a 13-month jail sentence and sex offender registration.

persons.name: Curt Anderson
persons.context: Author of the Associated Press article reporting on the court filing regarding Epstein's plea deal.

events.title: Epstein plea deal finalized
events.description: A once-secret plea deal ended a federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, allowing him to plead guilty to lesser state charges resulting in a 13-month jail sentence, financial settlements to victims, and sex offender registration.

events.title: Federal prosecutors file to uphold Epstein deal
events.description: Federal prosecutors filed a court document arguing that Epstein's 2008 plea deal must stand despite victims' objections that they were not consulted as required by law.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors argued in a 2019 court filing that Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 plea deal must stand despite objections from victims.
The 2008 deal ended a federal investigation and allowed Epstein to plead guilty to lesser state charges with a 13-month jail sentence.
The deal required financial settlements to dozens of Epstein's teenage victims and that he register as a sex offender.
Victims claim the deal should be thrown out because they were not consulted as required by the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
A federal judge must decide whether the violation of victims' rights allows for the agreement to be voided.
